headline: 'They have to do it' - Erik ten Hag sets challenge for young Man United trio vs Aston Villa
body: Manchester United travel to Aston Villa in the Premier League's late kick-off on Sunday looking to close the gap on the top four

Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag wants to see the likes of Rasmus Hojlund, Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo make an impact against a tougher opponent in Aston Villa today after their displays against West Ham last weekend.

The young trio were key to the 3-0 victory at Old Trafford last Sunday with Hojlund and Garnacho getting on the scoresheet and Mainoo enjoying another good performance in the heart of midfield. After Garnacho added United's second, the trio sat on the advertising hoardings together for an iconic celebration which mocked a similar one the Iron performed against them earlier in the season.

This image has been circulating across social media in the week since and has led many to claim these youngsters are the future of this United team. While Ten Hag is happy with what he has seen so far, he wants to see them produce consistency this afternoon.

He told MUTV: "Yeah, I think it's a very short period that they show it, they show potential but they have to take every game to bring them to a high level. And yeah, they have done it now in some games, it's the Premier League.
"But now they have to do it against better opposition like Sunday. There is a top-four team, can they do it? And that is their challenge.
"Can they do it in that game? Can they make the difference in that game? And to help the team win."

Before this weekend's action, Villa were fourth but they were leapfrogged by Tottenham Hotspur on Saturday after their 2-1 win over Brighton. Victory for United today shall move them within five points of Unai Emery's men and six points of Spurs in the final Champions League qualification spot.

headline: Manchester United make statement as former player Norman Whiteside affected by ticket decision
body: A number of fans and Man United great Norman Whiteside have been affected by a club decision on season tickets.
Manchester United great Norman Whiteside and a number of supporters have been angered by the club's decision to relocate their season ticket seats at Old Trafford.
Whiteside joined United as a teenager in 1978 before breaking into the first team. He scored 67 goals in 274 games in a red shirt before departing for Everton in 1989.

The Northern Irishman became the youngest player to score in both FA Cup and League Cup finals during his time at the club. Whiteside also became the youngest to play in a World Cup, breaking Pele's record when representing his nation aged just 17 years and 40 days.
Whiteside's career ended at the age of 26 due to injury, but he is still remembered fondly by fans for his contribution and his match-winning goal against Everton in the 1985 FA Cup final.
The 58-year-old is considered a United great, but that hasn't stopped him from being affected by a decision to relocate season ticket holders in block S122 at Old Trafford.
Whiteside is a platinum season ticket holder, which means he's held his ticket for over 25 years, and his name on his seat, but he now faces the prospect of being moved.

He is not alone and hundreds of other fans have been affected by the decision. Whiteside's wife, Dee, wrote on social media: "So, it doesn’t matter how long you’ve been a loyal supporter, doesn’t matter if you played for your club, United can just dump you from your seat when they feel like it, so they can expand exec seating. Absolute disgrace."

She continued: "I’d like to make clear that this post is not just about Norman. There are a whole block of loyal supporters who expressed their views to me at the West Ham game, but they feel as if they have no voice or platform to voice their anger.

"It’s not just about Norman, many of the 'United family' we sit with have been in that block for 20-30+ years, and are all really angry about this ENFORCED seat relocation. At a time when the football has been less than spectacular and the season ticket price is increasing."

The Manchester Evening News contacted United for comment and a spokesperson said: “We have the greatest respect for Norman as a legend of the club, and understand the disappointment caused to him and other season ticket-holders by seat relocations.

"There are various reasons why this happens, including, next season, the moving of matchday hospitality seats into consolidated blocks to address fan concerns about them being dispersed around the stadium.

"Other changes next season include the removal of hospitality seating from the Stretford End and installation of further rail seating in the North-West Quadrant, bringing benefits to many fans but also causing some disruption.

"No additional hospitality seats are being created at the expense of season ticket-holders — in fact hospitality seating will reduce by more than 500 next season. We are committed to working with all season ticket-holders affected by relocations, including Norman, to find them the best possible alternative seats elsewhere in the ground.”
Before that statement was made, a season ticket holder told the MEN: "I've sent an email and made three calls, but we've had little reassurance of where we will be moved to.
"I’m 52, my son is 19, we could move to another part of the ground. However, there are many older fans around us who have had their seat for decades and they have many friends around them.
"I think the club is underestimating the effect this could have on some of the fans and their mental health and welfare. I doubt many could handle the stairs in other parts of the ground."
Club sources have previously insisted they empathise with fans in such scenarios, while also indicating relocations within Old Trafford are often deemed necessary by staff.
All the very latest Man United news, views and transfer updates from the Manchester Evening News.
Manchester United return to action this afternoon as they face Aston Villa in the Premier League in search of a fourth consecutive victory in all competitions.

In recent weeks, the Red Devils have advanced into the fifth round of the FA Cup while also closing the gap to the top four and that can become smaller with a win at Villa Park today. However, Erik ten Hag will be forced to navigate the game without Lisandro Martinez after he picked up a knee injury in last weekend's 3-0 win against West Ham.

Aaron Wan-Bissaka is also expected to miss out after suffering a setback in training. Elsewhere, talk of Frenkie de Jong leaving Barcelona has understandably piqued interest from Old Trafford, however a number of European clubs are now interested in signing the Netherlands international and could rival United for his signature.
Follow the live blog below for all the very latest news and developments:
Dimitar Berbatov is expecting a four-goal thriller to take place at Villa Park between Manchester United and Aston Villa this afternoon.

"It's going to be a tough game for United," he told Betfair. "Both teams are coming from winning games, the momentum is with them. They both need the points. I’ve mentioned how I want Aston Villa to stay close with the top teams.
"United also need the points, they’re chasing the top four. I want to say United will win, but Villa are having a great season at the moment. I’ll go for the draw."
Prediction: 2-2
Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag will be forced into making at least one change to his starting XI that beat West Ham for this afternoon's clash against Aston Villa.

Lisandro Martinez, who has been impressive since returning from injury, suffered a fresh blow in the game with a problem is his knee expected to keep him out for up to eight weeks. Harry Maguire, Luke Shaw and Jonny Evans are among the names to potentially replace him, however a different trio have all dropped hints on their roles at Villa Park.
On Instagram, Alejandro Garnacho, Diogo Dalot and Antony have all posted pre-match graphics, an action usually done by a player set to be included from the off.
Barcelona star Frenkie de Jong could finally be heading to the Premier League this summer.

Manchester United were on the brink of signing the midfielder in 2022, however he chose to stay in Spain. Now, 18 months on, according to Spanish outlet Relevo, de Jong is open to leaving Barcelona this summer with the club also accepting his request.

The Netherlands international has frequently been linked with an exit from the Spanish club but his desire to remain at the Camp Nou has prevented an exit. Alongside Manchester United, Chelsea and Paris Saint-Germain are among the clubs monitoring his situation.

Erik ten Hag confirmed Lisandro Martinez has been ruled out for the Aston Villa match while Aaron Wan-Bissaka suffered a setback in his recovery from injury.

Martinez suffered ligament damage against West Ham last weekend and is set to be out of action for the next eight weeks. United went on to win 3-0 at Old Trafford with Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho on target.

headline: Erik ten Hag is responding to his biggest criticism at Manchester United this season
body: Man United take on Aston Villa in the Premier League on Sunday and Unai Emery's side have a tactical weakness to exploit.
Unai Emery has Aston Villa flying in the Premier League and challenging for Champions League qualification but a weakness in his side has emerged over the last two months.
Emery prefers his teams to play with a high defensive line in an attempt to defend away from the goal and he's stuck by those principles, despite Pau Torres being unavailable.

Torres is a pacy defender and he's a key cog in the system, but he sustained an ankle injury in December and Villa have suffered, losing twice (against Manchester United and Newcastle) and drawing two times (Sheffield United and Everton) in the last six league games.

The Spaniard briefly made a return from the bench during that run of games but that came too soon in his recovery. Torres has a chance of making the matchday squad when his side welcome United to Villa Park on Sunday afternoon but it's highly unlikely he will start the game.
Ezri Konsa and Clement Lenglet have started in Torres' absence and they are set to play again, which is good news for a United attacking front three that isn't short of pace.
Marcus Rashford, Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho have developed an understanding in recent weeks and they will find plenty of space behind Villa's defensive line to target.
At Old Trafford during the festive period, Villa had a two-goal lead against United at half-time, but they crumbled in the second half and lost the game 3-2 after a spirited comeback.

Garnacho scored a brace and Hojlund scored his first league goal. The pace of Garnacho caused havoc and Emery, speaking after the match, said his team needed to have more control and eradicate mistakes. He also described the contest as a 'missed opportunity'.
Villa's collapse on Boxing Day will serve as extra motivation this weekend, although Emery's tactics will not change and that should play into the hands of Erik ten Hag.
Ten Hag has said he wants United to be 'the best transition team in the world' and that approach will be used on Sunday, with Villa playing high and likely to have the majority of possession.
There have been accusations of a lack of a style of play levelled at Ten Hag this season, but now he has close to a fully-fit squad, how he wants to play is becoming clearer.
United have the pace and quality to hurt Villa on the counter-attack and they will find joy in the wide areas in such scenarios, meaning Rashford and Garnacho will have a key role to play.
Since Torres has been injured, Villa have shipped three goals against United and Newcastle, while conceding twice against Burnley. Their defensive line is gettable and should be exposed.
There have been countless moments over the last few weeks when the opposition has sent a ball over the heads of Konsa and Lenglet, which has led to the pair scrambling backwards.
Lenglet is considered the weak link and he was also vulnerable when on loan at Tottenham last season. Obviously, Barcelona do not allow quality players to leave on loan.

It's taken six months, but United's attackers head into this match in excellent form and it would be a surprise if one of those players didn't find the back of the net against Villa. Hojlund has four goals in his last four appearances and there should be no problem providing him with service.
Naturally, the players will have been briefed on Villa's high line at Carrington this week and players like Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo will be important in playing the killer pass.
Aston Villa are, theoretically, the perfect opponent for a United team capable on the break.

headline: I rejected the chance to manage Manchester United twice and became a Liverpool FC legend
body: "It's a big honour to talk to Sir Alex. For a manager it's nearly the best thing you can do, to sit there and listen."
"I didn't hear about a real offer. But, if there was, I could not have done it.
"I first had to finish the job with Dortmund and then think about other things.
"Maybe that is not smart, but that is my way."
A decade after David Moyes' sacking, Manchester United fans still wonder what might have been had they hired someone else instead.

There is an argument to suggest that whoever inherited the managerial role after Sir Alex Ferguson was doomed to fail, regardless of their own ability, though there are certainly a couple of compelling candidates to suggest otherwise.
Moyes was the man chosen by Ferguson to succeed him when he finally retired after 26 years in charge, though the legendary manager had also shown an interest in Jurgen Klopp.
FEATURE: Leroy Sane said I was the toughest opponent he faced but I never made it at United
FEATURE: I rejected Liverpool to sign for United and then quit City medical for Arsenal

The German coach had forged an impressive reputation for his 'heavy metal' football at Borussia Dortmund, which won two league titles, but he didn't want to leave the project while it still had so much potential.
Klopp even met with Ferguson to chat about his impending exit from Old Trafford and made it clear he was not currently in a position to take such a high-profile job.
"We spoke," Klopp said of their meeting in April 2013. "We spoke not a lot, but, for me, it was a lot. It was a big honour — the whole talk, to be honest. But I could not leave Dortmund.
"You are in April and you are in the middle of the planning for next season. You have this player and this player who are coming but then you are not there anymore? That doesn't work. Not in my life.
"I didn't hear about a real offer [from United] but, if there was, I could not have done it. I first had to finish the job with Dortmund and then think about other things.
"Maybe that is not smart but that is my way. It was the same at Mainz."

Although Ferguson was not able to lure the charismatic coach to Manchester, he certainly left a huge impression on him in the process. He added: "It's a big honour to talk to Sir Alex. For a manager, it's nearly the best thing you can do—sit there and listen.
"Maybe he is the greatest ever—the John Lennon of football. From my side, there is a big amount of respect. What he did is not easy for another manager to do."
Dortmund would go on to finish runners-up in the Bundesliga and Champions League that season, leaving Klopp more determined than ever to win a major trophy with the club before he left.
As Moyes set about the impossible job at Old Trafford, Klopp attempted the equally daunting task of trying to topple Bayern Munich after their historic treble a season earlier.
They would do so in the season-opening Super Cup, but once again, they would finish runners-up to Bayern in both the Bundesliga and the German Cup.

It hadn't put United off, though. Moyes was sacked after 10 months in charge, and Klopp was quickly made a favourite for the job along with Netherlands coach Louis Van Gaal, Atletico Madrid's manager Diego Simeone, and Paris Saint-Germain boss Laurent Blanc.
United inquired about the possibility of attaining his services again, but were told Klopp was insistent on honouring his contract at Signal Iduna Park.
Even before they had parted ways with Moyes, then executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward had flown out to meet with Klopp in an effort to convince him to take over at United. It didn't work.

“David Moyes’ short tenure at Old Trafford was coming to an end, and Klopp was United’s favourite to replace him, to bring back a sense of adventure to the Red Devils’ game,” Raphael Honigstein wrote in his biography on Jurgen Klopp called ‘Bring the Noise’.

“Woodward told Klopp that the Theatre of Dreams was ‘like an adult version of Disneyland’, a mythical place where, as the nickname suggested, the entertainment was world-class and dreams came true. Klopp wasn’t entirely convinced by that sales pitch—he found it a bit ‘unsexy’, he told a friend—but he didn’t dismiss the proposition out of hand either.”
United still hoped they could lure Klopp to Manchester, but the more he thought about it, the more he longed to end his time at Dortmund on a high.
"Man United is a great club and I feel very familiar with their wonderful fans," he said shortly afterwards. "But my commitment to Borussia Dortmund and the people is not breakable."
Klopp will leave Liverpool with a similar unbreakable bond this summer, and it is only natural for United supporters to wonder what might have been had he chosen Manchester over Merseyside instead.
While the post-Ferguson struggles continue to this day, Klopp will leave a Liverpool legend, even if he probably should have won more during his time at the club as well.

"I'm not in the mood to think about that [regrets]. I don't have to remember anything now,” Klopp told reporters after announcing his shock exit. “In my ideal world, the best memories are yet to come.
"I have no regrets but a lot of special memories."

Klopp has masterminded emphatic wins against every United manager he has faced, and those at Old Trafford will be determined to ensure he doesn't have another to add to his list before the season is out.
The Liverpool manager's impending exit might represent an opportunity missed, but now they can't miss the opportunity to take advantage of their possible demise when he leaves.

headline: Training promotions and Garnacho inspiration - how Manchester United are planning their next academy breakthroughs
body: The Man Utd academy continues to go from strength to strength under its head Nick Cox.

The words 'Every winner was once a beginner' are emblazoned in block white capitals on the scarlet red wall. Now-and-then images of Scott McTominay, Marcus Rashford and Alejandro Garnacho adorn the opposite wall.

The black-and-white portrait of McTominay was taken mere months after his Manchester United debut when he was aged 20. Rashford is no older than 16 and a 17-year-old Garnacho is hoisting the FA Youth Cup.

Tom Heaton and Paul McShane, back at Carrington in playing and coaching roles, also appear in an embrace from 2005 when United's reserves won the FA Premier Reserve League Shield at Charlton Athletic. "I don't know what Paul McShane's doing up there," jokes the affable academy head Nick Cox.
FROM 2022: 'Fernandes and Eriksen were both laughing' - the new mood at United's training complex

The message is clear: all five academy graduates - goalkeeper, defender, midfielder, winger and forward - have represented their countries and played regularly in the Premier League. All five drive through the Carrington barriers daily.

The photographs are married with monochrome shots of Manchester Town Hall and the city skyline. "We've spent so much time trying to reconnect everybody back to Manchester," Cox explains, "to our history but also to the city."

United have held academy staff meetings at the Museum of Science and Industry and invited folk from the city to present to them. Tony Walsh, a lifelong United fan who uttered the immortal This Is The Place poem days after the Manchester Arena attack, struck a chord. "It's the balance of a global brand but still feeling like an intimate family," Cox explains.

Inside the new academy gym, goalkeeper Tom Wooster is lifting weights with a coach, Shola Shoretire, Ashton Missin and Malachi Sharpe are loosening up on an exercise bike, preparing to brace the lashing rain.

When we eventually leave the £9million extension, four sodden and muddied lads are removing their boots after a morning training session. The doors to the new building opened in October, 20 years after the dedicated academy centre was opened by Sirs Alex Ferguson and Bobby Charlton.

The latest addition is part of the one-club approach, with the women's team also housed on the premises. Before construction started, the exterior of the original academy building was graced by a timeline of graduates from the men's and women's teams, starting with Busby Babes captain Roger Byrne and ending with women's captain Katie Zelem.

Cox has been the United academy head since 2019 and has overseen an exceptional period, even by the dream factory's standards. United have passed 4,000 consecutive matches with an academy member in a matchday squad, 22 have debuted for the first team, with Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo already indispensable.

The pair were totemic during the FA Youth Cup triumph in 2022, an uplifting run in an unedifying season. Cox coaxed Garnacho from Atletico Madrid to United via Zoom calls and the aid of an interpreter from his spare bedroom during lockdown in 2020. He wryly recalls his sons, aged 14 and 10 at the time, arguing outside.

Mainoo hails from Stockport and Brexit has forced United to look more intensely within their borders as they cannot recruit overseas talents aged under 18. That is a challenge the club have embraced and they have a precedent for blending homegrown British talent with continental clout.

"Think of the best United teams, the best United youth teams," Cox begins. "It's always been a core of local boys who understand the club, understand the city, what it means to the local people and then elite incomers, the best around, who bring innovation and maybe a different slant on things.

"I remember talking to Nicky Butt. He and the lads showed Ronaldo or Eric Cantona the club and they said, 'By the way, this is what I eat and I go and train twice a day.' So the lads were like, we'll follow suit.

"And that goes back to youth teams that would've had Bobby Charlton in it, arriving not from Manchester, or George Best, David Beckham, or Paul Pogba or whether it's Alejandro Garnacho. That's a bit of an unofficial blend.

"It's become a bit harder post-Brexit but our talent pool now is very much a UK talent pool, it changes the challenge a little bit but the concept is still the same. How do you make sure you've exhausted local talent?

"This place has to provide opportunities for local players, first and foremost, we've got to give everyone the chance. But then how do we add from further afield to make sure we've got a pool of high-potential talent that has to go and support a winning first team? That's the challenge."

United arranged flexible deadline day loans for Wooster, Sam Murray, Sam Mather and Sonny Aljofree to support local non-league clubs Macclesfield, Rochdale and Altrincham. Murray is one of the youngsters drying off downstairs while Mather and Aljofree have both been involved in first-team training sessions this month.

Cox has always downplayed the presence of unknown quantities suddenly rubbing shoulders with first-teamers in club imagery and footage. "It's always been commonplace but even more so under this manager, our boys will be in and around to support first-team training," he reiterates.

"There are probably two versions of support he needs. The academy provides two services: the academy has got to develop players who can play in that team and the other is to support that team to prepare to win.

"So recovery days, maybe when the manager's got a smaller group, we will add to that smaller group so they can have a proper, functional training session. So anyone who's not played, say there are eight remaining players, plus our 10 to make a training group so they can have a high-level functional session.

"But then on a normal training day there'll still be three, four or five lads over there. Some on merit, some just because it's the right positional fit. And the challenge for the boys is to really make a name for themselves. That jump to the first team.
"Everyone asks me, 'How do you decide? When do you decide?' There's never a day, there's always this movement back."

Erik ten Hag is prompt on providing feedback. "Darren Fletcher (technical director) is the biggest conduit, really," Cox stresses. "He is unbelievable at managing that period where they have one foot in each camp and then me and my staff are providing feedback as well.
"John Murtough is involved in there. There's this ongoing regular discussion around where they are at, what help do they need, what does the next month look like."

The academy is approaching another milestone. After Omari Forson's cameo against Wigan Athletic in last month's FA Cup third-round win, United are on 249 academy graduates to have played for the first team. Joe Hugill was an unused substitute that evening and has since joined Burton Albion on loan.
Willy Kambwala was an unlikely presence in the starting XI at West Ham United two days before Christmas. Such unexpected promotions are the beauty of United's faith in youth.
"Every debut brings us great pride," Cox beams. "As a youth developer, I take great pride from a number of sources about kids being successful.

"Debuts are obviously a more public-facing event that brings great satisfaction and noise and brings external interest. It’s amazing when young people debut here because when they come here that is what they set out to do.
"I enjoyed watching the debuts this year – Willy, Dan Gore, Omari – it’s great to see kids make debuts. We should definitely celebrate it and it is a landmark that they will remember forever.

"But it really is the beginning of the new journey. Only at 50 or 100 games can you start to think they might have cracked it. We have seen many kids at this club make one appearance and no more, and for them, they are focused and determined, driven. They know it’s a nice moment but they want to be in the team next week. They want to be in the team.

"They want to get to where Alejandro’s at. He has been in and around the squad. But now he is about to make his 20th consecutive appearance. That is when you start to think okay, 20 games in a row, that’s something. I am now starting to establish myself.

"249 is a really nice statistic because it encapsulates the great work of a number of amazing people over 90-odd years. That first debut was 1931, so all of those debuts leading us to this point, I think the beauty of that is that it’s not fabricated, it’s not forced, it’s just organic, and only recently have we just established that it’s 249.

"This club gives young people opportunities and puts players in the team. 249 is lovely. 250. Who will it be? That is the beauty of my job. We have a number of high-potential players. Knowing which one it might be next is harder but I am looking forward to seeing now how Kobbie has developed."
Mainoo may soon be on the wall at Carrington.

headline: 'I see it in the dressing room' - How Casemiro is helping Kobbie Mainoo at Manchester United
body: Kobbie Mainoo is having a breakthrough season at Man Utd and he has been taken under Casemiro's wing since the Brazilian returned from injury.

When Casemiro won his first Champions League title, Kobbie Mainoo was a nine-year-old pupil at Cheadle Catholic Junior School who had just embarked on his tentative first steps to a career in football.

Mainoo joined Manchester United that year, but back then making it into the first team at Old Trafford was a pipe dream, a fantasy that became reality for barely a handful of boys. But the prodigious midfielder has always had the game and the character to make an impression and by his teenage years, he was earmarked as someone who had more than a fair chance.

That progression has accelerated under Erik ten Hag this season. Mainoo caught the eye of the United manager in pre-season and although his progress was curtailed by an ankle injury, he was immediately restored to the senior set-up when he returned and has now started nine games in a row.

The last three of them have been alongside Casemiro, a five-times Champions League winner and 75-cap Brazil international who knows a thing or two about making it to the top of the game as a midfield player. The 31-year-old has taken his teammate 13 years his junior under his wing and it is a partnership that is showing signs of promise.

But if Casemiro has become Mainoo's minder at United, it is the younger man whose energy is bringing balance to United's midfield, making the former Real Madrid holding midfielder look much better than he did before suffering his own injury in November. The teenager from Stockport and the experienced midfielder from Sao Paulo are dovetailing on and off the pitch.
"Kobbie is very coachable, Casemiro has so much experience and Kobie will learn a lot from him and that can accelerate his development," he said.
“When they play together I think they can take benefit from each other.
“Casemiro takes that responsibility, he takes it to him, he is talking to him, I see it in the dressing room, I see it on the pitch in games, I see it in training.
“Of course he looking at his own game but he’s trying to help and support Kobbie. Absolutely there is that bond (between them)."

Casemiro struggled early in this season and speculation over a move away from Old Trafford intensified, with the midfielder still having three years remaining on a sizeable contract at the end of this season, but his performances since returning to the side have suggested he can remain a major influence on Ten Hag's team.
“He gives you calmness and composure on the ball, he gives you options, he sees the critical pass, so he is always a step ahead of his opponent to break lines," the United boss said.
"So he is a very important player for our game and we’re happy he’s back."
Mainoo's emergence at United has been particularly impressive, given he has come into a team that was struggling for form and confidence.

He played in the first game of the pre-season tour of the United States, impressing in midfield against a strong Arsenal side, and then started against Real Madrid in Houston only to pick up his injury in a tackle with Rodrygo in the early stages of that game.

As soon as he returned to fitness he was back in the team, starting at Goodison Park in November at a time when United's season was on the rocks and immediately adding an injection of energy and quality to the centre of the pitch. United have won six of the 11 games Mainoo has started this season, but lost 11 of the 22 he's not.
“It is more easy to integrate young talent into a successful team. That’s true," said Ten Hag.

“The conditions where we had to bring in Kobbie Mainoo were not so good that we knew beforehand that it would be a success. I had the confidence because I saw him performing and progressing in spring and summer.

“When I brought him in for the game against Arsenal, I didn’t have any doubts. But when he comes into the team there are many things he has to do on his own because when there are a lot of routines in the team it is much easier for him to come in.
“But we were not in that situation - and I don’t think this club has been in that situation for a long time.
“For many years, United have not been in that (successful) position, so we are building a team that can offer a foundation for young players to come in.
“We have to have a foundation so that we can add quality players to the squad to take the team to the next level.”

Although Mainoo has now started every game since the trip to Anfield on December 17, Ten Hag is treating him with care, withdrawing him at half-time at Nottingham Forest in the final game of 2023 and taking him off after 64 minutes against West Ham last weekend.
“I took him out on Sunday because it was the second game in nearly three days," he said. “I brought him out against Nottingham Forest because it was the third game in a week.
“I have to protect the player because first he has to get used to the Premier League intensity and then he has to get used to doing in every third day.
“You can’t train that. It’s impossible. You can’t train it in the Under-21s. You can only train this in the Premier League and the Champions League when you play every third day.
“That means you have to make considerations. It’s about the team - but it’s also about protecting young players so they don’t get injured.
“Kobbie was injured twice and we don’t want that situation again because it stops his progress."

headline: Manchester United transfer rebuild depends on 15 cup finals, says Erik ten Hag
body: Man Utd have pushed their way back into contention for Champions League football next season and they need the revenues that come with that competition.

Erik ten Hag admits he doesn't know how significant the impact will be on his transfer budget if Manchester United fail to qualify for next season's Champions League, but said the club will have more "financial power" if they do secure a return to the top table of European football.

United crashed out of Europe entirely before Christmas this season and face an uphill battle to secure a second successive season of Champions League football, with Sunday's trip to Villa Park pivotal in their fight to get back in the race for a top-four finish.

Fifth could yet be good enough for Champions League football if the Premier League finishes the season as one of the two top-performing leagues in Europe, but Ten Hag's side are six points behind Tottenham, who currently sit fifth, and eight points adrift of Aston Villa in fourth.

A run of 10 points from a possible 15 in the Premier League has put United back in the battle, but qualifying for the Champions League is no longer imperative solely for the prestige, but for the revenue it delivers as well at a time when clubs are struggling with the Premier League's stringent Profit and Sustainability rules (PSR).

United are particularly close to the limit of losses allowed by the league over three years and their failure to stay in Europe into the New Year this season pushed them closer to the precipice, with Ten Hag enduring his own dry January in the transfer market as a result. He admitted that he had looked to sign a striker on loan during the window but that there was no wriggle room at all to do any business.

That makes securing another year of Champions League cash vital ahead of Ineos' first summer transfer window in charge of United's football operations. They are set to appoint a new sporting director in time for the window, but if the season finishes with qualification for the Europa League or Europa Conference League, it will significantly reduce their ability to strengthen Ten Hag's squad.
"It’s very important to play Champions League, that is clear, we don’t have to discuss this," said Ten Hag.
"What exactly is the impact, that is what in this moment I don’t know, You have more financial power when you achieve the Champions League and that is our target, absolutely."

According to the Football Coefficient website, the prize money in the Champions League this season totals just over €2bn, while the Europa League prize money is €465m and the Europa Conference League just €235m. That is before the difference in matchday revenue and broadcast income is considered, with both substantially higher in the Champions League.

If United win at Villa Park on Sunday then they will close the gap to Unai Emery's side to five points. They have beaten top-half rivals Wolves and West Ham recently and earned a creditable draw at Old Trafford against Tottenham.

In his press conference ahead of the trip to the Midlands, Ten Hag said he had told his team at the start of January that every game was now equivalent to a cup final as United seek to close the gap to the teams above them.

"I said to the team from the start of January every game is now a final," he said. "That was also our approach to West Ham, this is a final, we have to take this challenge and see it as a final. That will be every day now from on."

headline: What TV channel is Aston Villa vs Manchester United on? Live stream and kick-off time
body: The latest Manchester United news as Erik ten Hag's side will look to make it three Premier League wins in a row when they travel to Villa Park.
Manchester United will be looking to make it three Premier League wins in a row and close the gap to the top four this weekend as they take on Aston Villa.
United make the journey to the West Midlands on Sunday afternoon with Villa currently sitting in fourth place in the Premier League. United are in sixth, eight points behind their opponents.

Last week saw Erik ten Hag’s team pick up maximum points. A dramatic late 4-3 win over Wolves was followed by a comfortable 3-0 home victory over West Ham thanks to goals from Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho.

Both of those players were on the scoresheet when United last met Villa. After finding themselves 2-0 down at half time, a double from Garnacho and the winner from Hojlund saw United come back to record a 3-2 win at Old Trafford.
Fans will be hoping for a similar result this weekend, but maybe with less drama. Here is everything you need to know about following Sunday’s Premier League clash.
The game takes place on Sunday, 11 February 2024 with kick-off at 4.30pm. The match is being played at Villa’s Villa Park.

Yes, the game is being shown live on Sky Sports. Coverage on Sky Sports Premier League and Main Event starts at 4.00pm, following West Ham vs Arsenal. Sky customers with a Sky Sports subscription will be able to stream the game live on Sky Go, while Virgin Media customers with a Sky Sports subscription can watch via the Sky Sports app.
The game is also being shown live around the world if you; 're not in the UK. NovaSports is showing the game in Greece, while SuperSPORT will be broadcasting the game in South Africa.

Highlights of the game will be available to watch live on Match of the Day 2 at 10.30pm on Sunday on BBC One, it can be streamed live and after the show via BBC iPlayer. Highlights will also be available on the Sky Sports app, and Manchester United website shortly after the full-time whistle.

The Manchester Evening News will be at Villa Park and will bring you all of the action and reaction before, during, and after the game. You will be able to follow via our live blog which goes live a few hours before kick-off.

headline: Manchester United have £496m NFL blueprint for Old Trafford which Tottenham haven't capitalised on
body: Manchester United have a crucial decision to make over whether to stick or twist with Old Trafford - and a new stadium could open up lucrative options for naming rights
With Sir Jim Ratcliffe reportedly wanting to create a ‘Wembley of the North’ for Manchester United, there is some discussion over what that should look like.

Old Trafford has been United’s home since 1910, and while it may look a lot different now than it did then, it is nonetheless woven into the fabric of the football club, the scene of some of its greatest triumphs. But there is an awkward conversation to be had over whether sense trumps sentimentality, and whether or not the club chooses to spend money on redeveloping their existing home or start afresh on land adjacent, focusing on creating a world-class stadium for a club that wants to be at the vanguard of the game moving into a new era.

Tottenham Hotspur had a key decision to make when it came to White Hart Lane: remained wedded to tradition or start afresh. They chose the latter and what they now have is a £1bn stadium, one of the world’s state-of-the-art sporting venues, where everything is designed to generate revenue beyond a matchday: from the contract that exists with the NFL to stage regular season games - with the retractable pitch all but confirming the stadium as the long-term home for the NFL in the UK, a market it could land a franchise in further on down the line - to the F1 Karting Experience that now exists underneath the stadium.

The Tottenham Hotspur Stadium was debt-financed, but there is good debt and there is bad debt. If a business can service that debt and it doesn’t impede the growth of the business, with the debt used to grow revenues into the future, there is little to be concerned about. That can be seen through Spurs having the best position when it came to the Premier League’s Profit and Sustainability Rules (PSR) due to investment in infrastructure being an allowable loss when it came to the £105m three-year loss limit.

It is an investment that positions Spurs perfectly to take advantage of the trajectory of the modern game, and one that will likely see them emerge as a force over the next decade or so due to their ability to spend sustainably. They still have one ace left up their sleeve, too.

The ground is still called the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium after nothing came of exploratory naming rights talks with some major blue-chip firms. There is no firm decision on whether or not they will go down that route, and whether the identity of the club in the stadium name is worth foregoing the selling of rights.

United will have that consideration too, should they decide to press the reset button and pursue a purpose-built stadium where they can plan down to the finest detail how it would benefit the club to the maximum. A new stadium, in the long run, would likely be the most cost-effective, and redeveloping the land around it would afford the club the chance to create an entertainment hub that would see it in use all year round.

It would also allow them to sidestep the awkward issue of naming rights, something that can be of tremendous value to clubs, providing long-term financial security that emboldens spending. At present, there is very little chance of United renaming Old Trafford as it is. The backlash would be beyond intense. The same could be said if Liverpool owners Fenway Sports Group decided to rename Anfield. It is a revenue stream that could exist, but one that won’t.

A new stadium unbinds tradition and attachment and allows for commercial arms of clubs to greater monetise the premises in which these clubs operate. While that may seem a rather bleak way of looking at football tradition, the fact is that we are now through the looking glass when it comes to how the intersection of money and football come together. You can’t have the big signings on the big wages without the big cheques arriving through the door.

North American sport has capitalised on naming rights opportunities in recent years. While certain teams who have remained in their storied stadiums, such as the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park, have remained loyal to tradition, others with new venues have sought to make the most of the riches on offer. The Glazer-owned Tampa Bay Buccaneers NFL team sold their stadium naming rights for a new stadium built in 1998 to a financial services firm, Raymond James. That deal is still in place and has been renewed until 2028, so there is some form from the United owners for doing such a deal.

In Los Angeles, last year saw the biggest stadium naming rights deal in sporting history when the newly-built stadium for the Chargers and Rams was christened the So-Fi Stadium after the finance firm acquired the rights in a 30-year, $625m (£496m) deal. Given that deal was struck in 2019, and the size of United, more than £500m for their rights would be a very conservative estimate over the same period.

Brands want naming rights for new stadia, and the amount they are willing to pay keeps on climbing. Manchester United is one of the sport’s most recognisable brands globally, and a best-in-class stadium would attract enormous interest from major companies wanting to attach themselves to the United brand. Deals of such longevity also provide owners with greater security over finance, in the same way that longer broadcast deals do.

Whether or not United choose to go down the route of redevelopment or a new development remains to be seen, and it won’t be a swift process to reach a conclusion. There are greater financial benefits to be realised by breaking from tradition, but given that the game feels like it is battling for its soul more now than at any stage in the past, fans may feel it is a bridge too far.
Sign up to our new weekly newsletter, the Bottom Line, which will bring you exclusive reporting on the financial issues affecting the future of football.

From the happenings at the biggest clubs, at home and abroad, interviews with the people who make the big decisions behind the scenes - Dave Powell, Chief Business of Football Writer for Reach Plc, will be keeping newsletter subscribers informed and doing deep dives into the business of Premier League clubs, the EFL pyramid, US sports and more.
The Bottom Line is currently offering 50% off annual subscriptions.
So, for the latest news on the finances of Premier League clubs from Dave Powell, subscribe here.

headline: We simulated Aston Villa vs Manchester United to get a score prediction and there was a shock scorer
body: Man United make the trip to Villa Park on Sunday, with Erik ten Hag's side facing Aston Villa in the Premier League
Manchester United will be looking to tighten their grip on sixth place and close the gap on the top four when they take on Aston Villa in the Premier League on Sunday.

Three wins in a row in all competitions send United into the clash with Villa in high spirits, with Alejandro Garnacho scoring a brace as Erik ten Hag's side beat West Ham United 3-0 in their last outing. 11 goals in the last three games put United in their best goalscoring form all season, and they will need to be at their best in front of goal on Sunday if United want to secure three points.

Villa have had one of the best home records in England this season, but two home defeats on the bounce make this the perfect time for Ten Hag's side to make the trip to the West Midlands. The two sides last met in December, with United coming from two goals down to win 3-2 at Old Trafford.
To complete this simulation, we used EA FC 24 and updated the squads with the latest injuries and suspensions.
We predict that the hosts could line up in a 4-4-2 formation, with their starting XI as follows: Martinez; Cash, Carlos, Lenglet, Moreno; McGinn, Luiz, Kamara, Bailey; Diaby, Watkins.
We predict that United could set up in a 4-3-3 formation, with their line-up as follows: Onana; Dalot, Varane, Maguire, Shaw; Casemiro, Mainoo, Fernandes; Garnacho, Hojlund, Rashford.

The opening 30 minutes at Villa Park saw the possession and chances split evenly between the two sides, with Moussa Diaby coming closest when he forced Andre Onana into a fantastic save one-on-one. United were a constant threat on the counter, and just before the break, Ten Hag's side were able to snatch the lead.

As Boubacar Kamara and Douglas Luiz exchanged passes in midfield, pressure from Kobbie Mainoo forced them into giving up possession, with Bruno Fernandes on the scene to pick up the loose ball. A fantastic through ball sent Rasmus Hojlund one-on-one, and Emiliano Martinez was wrong-footed as the striker slotted home to make it 1-0.

United were the better side after the restart, and Diogo Dalot should've made it 2-0 in the 67th minute when he burst through on goal and rattled the post from a dangerous position. The pressure continued to build, and Ten Hag's side were able to secure the victory in the 84th minute as they doubled their lead.

United picked up four consecutive corners late on, with the visitors forcing Martinez into making big saves from each set piece. There was nothing the 'keeper could do for the goal, with Harry Maguire leaping highest to guide his header into the bottom corner for 2-0.
What do you think the final score will be? Let us know in the comments!
Follow the MEN's United coverage on TikTok and YouTube, and subscribe to the Manchester is Red podcast

It's the January transfer window once again, but despite United's indifferent start to the season, it remains to be seen whether they'll be able to bring any new players to Old Trafford this month. While the emphasis this January is on outgoings, with several players set to be sold or loaned out, there remains a possibility of a loan signing or two before February arrives.

Our team of experts are on top of all the goings-on at Old Trafford for the remainder of the window and beyond, and you can get the latest updates and inside information to your phone by joining our new free WhatsApp community. You can also join the 50,000 (and growing!) band of United fans who are following our WhatsApp Channel.

We also treat our community members to special offers, promotions, and adverts from us and our partners. If you don’t like our community, you can check out any time you like. If you’re curious, you can read our Privacy Notice.

headline: I said no to Manchester United and was in League One a month later - I made a massive mistake
body: Having played for Man United, Daniel Nardiello achieved something special in his career. During his time at Old Trafford, he worked alongside club legends such as Rio Ferdinand, Gary Neville and Roy Keane - who were all key in his development.

Not many people can say they have played for Manchester United. For those that can, whether you played 963 times like Ryan Giggs, or once like Kieran Lee, the honour of pulling on the famous shirt is exactly the same.

Daniel Nardiello managed four matches. The forward burst onto the scene with Wolves and played for the FA's School of Excellence at Lilleshall at the age of 14. Having impressed for his club, it wasn't a surprise when rival teams started to show an interest in him - and when United came calling, it was difficult to ignore.

United were winning trophies for fun at that time, but Sir Alex Ferguson was always keen for the academy to strengthen and improve with emerging talent. The Reds were one of several sides interested in Nardiello, but the lure of one day playing under the lights at Old Trafford - for the most famous manager in world football - was just too special to turn down.
OPINION: £72m signing might stop United making club-record summer move

With Nardiello registered under schoolboy terms at Wolves, a Football League Appeals Committee ordered United to pay £200,000 compensation for his services, including other potential add-ons. On the pitch, meanwhile, it didn't take the frontman too long to progress through the ranks with the Reds, and he turned professional in October 1999.

Despite having to wait more than a year to make his debut, it finally came in November 2001. It was in a 4-0 League Cup defeat at Arsenal - as part of a much-changed United side - but for Nardiello, it was an understandably proud moment.

"Don't get me wrong, looking back at it now, from a 40-year-old's perspective, it's something I'm extremely proud of that I managed to do, not many people manage to pull on that shirt and represent Manchester United's first team", Nardiello told the Manchester Evening News. "So it's something I look back on with real pride.

"At the time, I was an 18-year-old kid and you sort of just take it in your stride at that age, so I didn't really realise the achievement of playing for Manchester United's first team until my older age and when I retired.

"I was a confident young lad and I had confidence in myself to be playing football at the highest level, so it [his debut] just seemed like the next step in my development, and to do it at Arsenal at Highbury is something I am really proud of and something I am glad I wasn't nervous about at the time."

When he was coming through at United, Nardiello was training alongside the likes of Roy Keane, Gary Neville and Rio Ferdinand. It was a time when the Reds were winning trophies consistently, so it is somewhat unsurprising that he had to wait a while - more than a year, to be precise - to make his second appearance for the club.

Nardiello was working with some of the best footballers in the country, and it was their commitment to winning and attention to detail that was so impressive. Keane, in particular, was someone who the United youngster admired. The Irishman, as is well documented, was desperate to succeed at Old Trafford. He expected the best of himself and his teammates.

Yet, despite some of the negative stories about the former Reds captain, Nardiello spoke fondly of his time working with the midfielder, even if he did stop training in the middle of a session - without any sort of warning - during an international break.

"Keane was unbelievable. If training wasn't right... I actually remember him stopping training a couple of times to make sure the lads were doing the work and doing things right," Nardiello said. "He expected 100% effort and commitment from lads all the time in training.

"I remember it was an international break and there was a lot of reserve team lads training with the first-team lads who were not on international duty and he stopped the session to make sure lads were doing the right things and making sure the passing was correct and that type of thing.

"But on top of that, it was the encouragement levels he gave you as well. I don't know if people saw this but the encouragement he gave specifically to me was second to none, he guided me in certain aspects and also encouraged me a lot. I remember him playing a couple of reserve team games and it was nothing but good advice and guidance and encouragement.

"Of course when things weren't going right on the pitch, he may shout and scream at certain players for not doing things, but that's what leaders do, they expect the best. For me, he's one of the best captains that United have probably ever had, or that world football has ever seen."

While Nardiello never actually played with Keane, he did spend time in the same squad as another Reds legend. In fact, his last appearance for the club came in place of Cristiano Ronaldo, with the attacker replacing the Portuguese ace in the latter stages of a shock 2-0 defeat to West Brom in the 2003/04 Carling Cup.

It was Ronaldo's first appearance in the competition, and while it ended in a loss, it was clear how talented he was and what he could bring to Old Trafford. The tricky winger went on to make 346 appearances for the Reds, registering 145 goals and 64 assists. For Nardiello, it was clear that his teammate was destined for greatness - even after a surprise loss to the Baggies.

He said: "He [Ronaldo] was clearly an unbelievably talented young lad when I was there, I think when he signed he was 18 or 19. You could see in training and in games that he obviously had a lot of ability and potential, but I don't know if anyone would have predicted how amazing his career would be.

"The fact that he's probably one of the greatest players to have ever lived, I don't think many people would have predicted that. A lot is down to the guidance he had under Sir Alex, but also down to his own mentality, work rate and belief in himself.

"To score the number of goals he has, I don't think anyone who maybe watched him in the first couple of seasons at Manchester United would have predicted the level he actually got to, but fair play to him because he was just an absolute monster and still is!"

The majority of Ronaldo's appearances for United came as a starter. Nardiello, on the other hand, made just one start, in the League Cup, but unlike in the other three matches, he was on the winning side on that occasion.

United secured a 2-0 victory over Leicester City in November 2002, with Nardiello in the attack alongside Diego Forlan and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. Behind him were Quinton Fortune and David Beckham, while Ferdinand, David May, John O'Shea, Gary Neville and Phil Neville formed the defence. Roy Carroll completed a strong line-up for the Reds.

Much like the feeling of making his debut for the club, achieving his first start for United - and one that came in a victory - was pleasing for Nardiello. After three substitute appearances and three defeats, he was finally part of a winning side under Ferguson.

"It was great starting a game and again there were no nerves or anything like that, it was just a case of trying to do as well as I could on the day," Nardiello added. "Looking back now and looking at the starting line-up from that game, it was a really strong starting XI, with me being probably the weakest link in the starting XI.

"It was great that Sir Alex had the confidence to put me in and to say I've played alongside those lads, although I did it in training and a few reserve team matches, it was amazing and something I look back on with pride."

With Nardiello having spent time out on loan in the 2003/04 season, it became clear that his time at Old Trafford was starting to come to an end. The striker impressed during a one-month loan to Swansea City, but it was his stint with Barnsley that really helped to kick-start his career.

He scored two goals on his debut and bagged seven times in 16 games before returning to United. Having become a fan favourite with the Barnsley fans, he returned again to Oakwell on a season-long loan for the following campaign. Despite struggling with injuries, Nardiello still managed 30 games, scoring seven goals.

Upon his return to United at the end of the season, he had an open and honest conversation with Ferguson. The Scotsman offered him the chance to remain at the club but suggested that it would be better for Nardiello's career if he moved on. In the end, it was decided that he would be released upon the expiry of his contract, with Nardiello making a permanent move to League One side Barnsley, though he now admits he should have extended his stay at Old Trafford.

"I kind of knew it was coming towards an end, I got to a certain age where I was playing regularly on loan at decent-sized clubs, but it wasn't Premiership clubs," Nardiello said. "I got called into the office by Sir Alex, had a sit-down with him and he said he could give me another year, but he said he thought I should go out on a permanent basis and play regular football.
"I think he was just being kind saying he could give me an extra year, looking back I probably should have said, 'Give me that extra year then' but it seemed like the natural end to my time there.

"I don't think I was upset, it was just one of those things you have to deal with in football. It was an end of an era in terms of leaving Manchester United, but I was just focused on building my career."

Given that Ferguson gave him the chance to represent United, Nardiello still has a lot of love and respect for the legendary figure. He suggested it was a 'privilege' to play under him - and recalled a meeting with the Scot years after he had left Old Trafford. It was, in many ways, a perfect anecdote to describe Ferguson the man, rather than the manager.

"He [Ferguson] was obviously a huge success while I was there, and after I left he achieved so much more as well," he said. "He's the best manager that's ever lived and I was lucky enough to play under him, albeit in a handful of games. It was a privilege to work under him and learn from him.

"He did go into a lot of detail with every individual player. I remember when I was coming towards the end of my football career, I actually bumped into him at The Alexandra Hospital. I was having a check-up on an injury and he was having a check-up on something and we happened to be seeing the same doctor.

"He came over to me and said, 'You're doing really well, scoring goals at Bury'. I was thinking, 'How does he even know, 10 or 15 years after I'd left the club, that I'm at Bury towards the end of my career?'. How he knew that after however many years it was, to come up to start speaking to me, the physio I was with was in shock!"

Nardiello, like many former players, reflects on his career with pride. In fact, his first appearance for the club came alongside two other debutants - Lee Roche and Jimmy Davis. Given that Nardiello featured alongside both Roche and Davis in the 4-0 defeat to Arsenal in their first showing in a United shirt, he will always be connected to the pair in some way.

In August 2003, Davis - who had left the Reds to join Watford on loan - was travelling to Vicarage Road for their opening game of the season against Coventry City when he collided with a lorry and died. He was 21 years old at the time of his death.

Understandably, Nardiello admitted Davis' death came as a shock to everyone. It was a difficult period for anyone who knew Davis, but now, two decades on from his death, Nardiello is able to speak glowingly about his former teammate - both as a player, but also as a person.

"The anniversary of his death always pops up on social media, and you always give him a thought," he said. "It was a huge shock, and I know it's easy for me to say now, but he was an unbelievable talent, an unbelievable player. Whether he was at United or somewhere else, he would have had an unbelievable career. He genuinely was excellent, one of the better youth team players, for sure.

"He could even have done it at Manchester United on a regular basis, that's how good he was. It was extremely sad because a guy I've grown up with, played regularly with. He was a great character in and around the changing room, everyone loved him. His family are lovely, they were not too far from where my family are from in the Midlands.
"Heartbreaking really, really sad what happened there and may he rest in peace."

United paid tribute to Davis during their 2003 FA Community Shield victory against Arsenal, with both teams wearing black armbands during the match. Later in the season, the Reds - at the suggestion of Keane - paid tribute to him once again. After lifting the 2004 FA Cup, the players changed into shirts printed with Davis' name and squad number, 36.

Davis made just one senior appearance for United, but he was clearly a popular member of the group and played his part in and around the training ground. Like Nardiello, he managed to achieve something that the majority of people can only ever dream of.
Playing for Manchester United, at Old Trafford, under Sir Alex Ferguson, was a dream come true for Daniel Nardiello. He managed something special, and no one can ever take that away from him.

headline: Unai Emery names three key Manchester United players and explains Aston Villa's plan to win
body: Aston Villa have lost their last two games at Villa Park after 3-1 defeats to Newcastle and Chelsea and face Man United in the Premier League next up on Sunday
Aston Villa boss Unai Emery says his side must stop Manchester United goalkeeper Andre Onana from playing out from the back in their upcoming Premier League fixture if they are to win.

United travel to Villa Park on Sunday to face an Aston Villa side that has seen their hopes of a top four finish stumble somewhat in recent weeks. Last weekend's 5-0 win over relegation-threatened Sheffield United was only Villa's second win in the Premier League since Christmas and Emery's side we dumped out of the FA Cup in their fourth round replay against Chelsea midweek.
Speaking in his pre-match press conference ahead of the game, Emery highlighted Luke Shaw, Diogo Dalot and Casemiro as being key players for United.

Admitting the upcoming match is crucial, the Villa boss said: "It's a new challenge for us, it's a new challenge for our supporters and it's a new challenge in Villa Park to feel strong like we were. This is a challenge. We have to be together, we have to use our positive energy everybody. Each individual fan has to support us with their energy.

"Even like that, it's going to be a very, very difficult match because they will need to get points and close the difference to us in the table. When we're facing matches like this of course we have to be consistent in 38 matches but it's a key match. We have to try to create a great atmosphere with our supporters."

Several players including Ezri Konsa (knee), Lucas Digne (hamstring), Emi Buendia (knee), Jhon Duran (hamstring) and Tyrone Mings (knee) are all out due to injuries. But Emery believes if his side can stop United from playing out from the back then they should be in with a chance of claiming the three points.

Emery commented: "We have to try to stop them (United), starting with the goalkeeper because his build-up is fantastic. Their centre-backs like to play, building up and controlling ball possession, trying to get good combinations on the pitch.
"Luke Shaw is very dangerous and Diogo Dalot is in a good moment. Casemiro is a very important player for them; they have very good wingers and strikers and that is my concern."

headline: Man United 'monitoring' Brazilian starlet dubbed 'new Endrick' amid €30m claim and more rumours
body: The 18-year-old Brazilian will attract a lot of attention in the summer market but Man United face fierce competition to land him
Manchester United are reportedly among the clubs monitoring Palmeiras wonderkid Thalys.

The 18-year-old is regarded as a top prospect by Palmeiras, having come through their academy set-up. He is likely to become the next big money sale after the £51million fee they received for Endrick from Real Madrid in 2022.
According to Spanish newspaper AS, Thalys is also being monitored by Barcelona, Chelsea and Juventus. It is said that the Brazilian side are expecting to receive a similar fee for the striker.

The report adds that Palmeiras have already rejected an offer from Italy for the youngster. Regarded as a 'new Endrick', Thalys has participated in several training sessions with the first team, though he is yet to make a senior appearance under Abel Ferreira.

United were linked with a number of attacking additions during the winter window but had a quiet January amid concerns over Financial Fair Play and with Sir Jim Ratcliffe's minority takeover of the club still awaiting Premier League ratification. However, the club are expected to splash the cash out in the summer with Raphael Varane due to leave at the end of his contract in June.

Elsewhere, United and Tottenham are said to be 'ready to make an offer' of around €30m for Juventus defender Dean Huijsen as per Tutto Juve. Huijsen, currently on loan at Roma, reportedly has interest from United, Borussia Dortmund and RB Leipzig.
Football Italia add that the Italian giants are not ready to sell Huijsen yet and are hopeful his value will increase.

Finally, Barcelona's Frankie de Jong, a long-term target for United is said to be reconsidering his future. He was initially linked with a move to Old Trafford in 2022 after Erik ten Hag's arrival at Old Trafford.
Spanish journalist Lluis Canut, has shed light on the factors reportedly influencing his reconsideration as per Mundo Deportivo.

"De Jong has not given the green light, but he is no longer closing the door on leaving Barca as he did two seasons ago, when he had interest, especially from Manchester United, in going to play with the coach who had him at Ajax - Ten Hag," Canut told Esport3.

"At the moment, De Jong is a little disappointed by the situation at Barca because he has not managed to turn the expectations that had been generated at the time when he signed into important titles. De Jong would be willing to leave Barca at the end of this season."

headline: Mason Greenwood has addressed Manchester United decision as new transfer option emerges
body: Latest Manchester United transfer rumours involving Mason Greenwood
The future of Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood remains uncertain as he enjoys a positive run for La Liga side Getafe.

The 22-year-old has five goals and four assists in 19 matches in Spain's top-flight. He joined the Madrid-based club during the summer transfer window after being exiled by United following an investigation by the police and internally in January 2022.
Greenwood faced accusations of rape, assault and controlling and coercive behaviour, but the Crown Prosecution Service dropped the case after a lengthy investigation that concluded last year.

With less than 18 months remaining on his contract at Old Trafford, the United academy product will likely leave Erik ten Hag's side. It remains to be seen where his next destination will be, but he has enjoyed his start to life in Spain, and reports suggest that he could be attracting interest.
Here is a round-up of the latest news.
Diego Simeone's Atletico Madrid emerged as a possible transfer destination for Mason Greenwood.

The Spanish side missed out on a move for Juventus and former Everton striker Moise Kean after the deal fell through. According to The Telegraph, the Argentine tactician is looking to bolster his strike options, and the one-time England international is said to have attracted attention.
It has been claimed that Greenwood has "impressed other Spanish teams" with his performances this season. The 22-year-old featured during their dramatic 3-3 draw with Atletico earlier this season.

Antoine Griezmann scored twice and seemingly fired Los Rojiblancos to three points until late goals from Oscar Rodriguez and Borja Mayoral earned a point. Greenwood's performance earned praise from the France international Griezmann; he said: "In the end, you hold on... Greenwood hurt us a lot, we couldn't stop him at the end of the game and two goals came."
Mason Greenwood was back in the spotlight following Getafe's 2-0 defeat against Real Madrid as La Liga began an investigation.

It is alleged that Jude Bellingham made an offensive remark during a recent fixture between Getafe and Real. The incident prompted a response from Getafe boss Jose Bordalas, who said: "I know the same thing that you know. It’s not up to me, it’s the club, La Liga and the Federation that have to make an assessment about it.
"The only thing that I can say is that I ask for respect from Mason Greenwood because he is a great guy. He is a man who respects everyone and has exemplary behaviour."
Despite the media attention, the 22-year-old was left undeterred, as he was on target for Getafe in a 1-1 draw at Real Betis to keep Bordalás' side in midtable.
Mason Greenwood revealed in January that he is 'happy' at Getafe.

His effort against Betis made it two goals in three games as speculation emerged over where he could move next. Barcelona are also said to be rivalling Atletico Madrid for the 22-year-old's signature, but nonetheless, the Englishman is enjoying his time in the Spanish capital.

"Everything's fine," he said, speaking to Getafe's official YouTube channel. "I adapted pretty quickly. [My] team-mates took me under their wing and I've just been happy ever since, coming here and training, playing the games. I'm happy.
"The fans mean a lot to me. The best feeling so far is when I scored my first goal here at the stadium and it meant a lot to me, I heard the fans quite a lot.
"We had the training day and a lot of fans came out to watch. We appreciate the fans. They're like an extra man out there on the pitch when they're there supporting us."

headline: Jadon Sancho has nightmare night for Borussia Dortmund as Manchester United loanee misses sitter
body: The latest Man United news as the winger returned from injury to play the last few minutes of the side's 3-0 win in the Bundesliga on Friday night.
Manchester United loanee Jadon Sancho had a night to forget as he made his return from injury for Borussia Dortmund.

After missing the Bundesliga clash against Heidenheim with a muscle injury last week, the winger returned to the squad for the clash against Freiburg on Friday night. Dortmund came out as 3-0 winners, thanks to a double from Donyell Malen and a goal from Niclas Fullkrug.

Sancho replaced Marco Reus just after Dortmund’s third goal in the 88th minute. Around three minutes after making his way onto the pitch, the 23-year-old had the perfect chance to score his first goal since returning to the club.

Dortmund got in behind the Freiburg defence, and Julian Brandt crossed the ball for Sancho at the back post. A slip by the goalkeeper meant that he had the full goal to aim for, but his left-footed effort only looped into the air and into the goalkeeper’s thankful arms.

The appearance, streamed on Sky Sports Football's YouTube channel, was Sancho’s third since signing for Dortmund in the January window. He recorded two assists in his first two appearances against Darmstadt 98 and FC Koln.

Earlier this week, Dortmund sporting director Sebastian Kehl said that it’s unlikely that the England man’s move to the club will become permanent in the summer. "Unfortunately for both players [Ian Maatsen and Jadon Sancho], neither option was really realistic. If you know what we got for Jadon Sancho two and a half years ago, then you know also that it might now be very, very difficult," he told Sky Sports Germany.
"We naturally advocated for an option with him - and also with Ian - but the negotiating position was not such that we could implement it and so we will accept it for now."

Sancho and Dortmund will be back in action next weekend when they take on Wolfsburg in the Bundesliga. The win on Friday night left them in fourth place in the table, although most of their rivals now have a game in hand over them.

headline: The clues making Kobbie Mainoo's Manchester United story impossible to ignore
body: Man United youngster Kobbie Mainoo has been excellent since coming into the team and England have been watching.

Just a few days after Manchester United's win against Everton in October, the chatter among journalists while watching training at Carrington was about Kobbie Mainoo and whether he could make the England squad for this summer's European Championship.

A raucous atmosphere was expected at Goodison Park due to Everton's point deduction but that didn't stop Erik ten Hag from giving Mainoo his first start in the Premier League. Unsurprisingly, the unflappable Mainoo was unfazed by the hostility and he delivered an exceptional performance which saw him pick up the man of the match award.

"The biggest compliment I can pay him, and it hurts to say this, I hope people can take this in the right spirit," said Gary Neville, who was on commentary for Sky Sports. "He looked like a Manchester City player. Honestly, I was watching him and thinking, ‘that’s a player that Pep Guardiola will be looking at and thinking, ‘I want him in my midfield'.
"Thankfully United have got him because he looks so composed, so graceful, always looking over his shoulder, knowing where everyone is, letting it run across his body."
Mainoo's performance was special. It generated a buzz. He's been excellent since making that first league start and he's currently one of the first names on the team sheet.
Each challenge Mainoo has faced, he has overcome. There have been tests away at Galatasaray, Newcastle and Liverpool and those appearances only enhanced his reputation.
Mainoo had been the academy's best-kept secret for a few years and that is no longer the case because - while he is still just 18 years old - he looks destined for the top of the sport.
Those who know Mainoo best paint a picture of a grounded, likeable young man and sources have indicated they would be surprised if he ever got ahead of himself.

Mainoo recently pulled over, despite being at the start of a roundabout, to sign autographs for fans who had waved him down. He also made a heartwarming gesture when inviting a supporter and his son to Old Trafford, following the loss of a family member, whose last game watching United before passing away was against Wolves when he scored a late match-winning goal.
Those small gestures show that 'he gets it' and sources have previously stressed he has the talent and temperament to succeed, which points to an exciting future.
Mainoo is remarkably mature on the pitch and away from it for someone his age and if he continues to perform at the same level, the calls for him to play for England will only grow louder.
The midfielder's family background is Ghanaian and he regularly visits the country. He is eligible to play for the Back Stars but he's expected to pick England for his international career.
Mainoo has represented the Three Lions throughout the youth levels and, last year, a source close to the player confidently said he would progress to play for England.

Ghana's FA recently declared their interest in Mainoo and told The Times: “Ghana is interested in monitoring, attracting, and persuading all eligible talents for its various national teams. Kobbie is definitely one of such incredible talents, and the Association will love to work with him and many like him home and abroad.”
Mainoo will have to make a decision and that might be required sooner than he anticipated because he has an outside chance of making England's squad for 2024.
Gareth Southgate plays with a midfield three and Jude Bellingham and Declan Rice are deservedly automatic starters, but the remaining midfield squad positions are up for grabs.

Kalvin Phillips has made a disappointing start to life at West Ham, Jordan Henderson has hurried back to Europe to sign for Ajax after making the move to Saudi Arabia in a PR disaster and Conor Gallagher is out of form in a struggling Chelsea side. The other options, James Ward-Prowse, Ruben Loftus-Cheek and Curtis Jones, also fail to inspire, whereas Cole Palmer deserves to be included.
Gareth Southgate vowed to select players based on form and not reputation when he was appointed England manager and Mainoo could be included in his squad if that is true.
There's plenty of football to be played from now until the end of the season. Mainoo has been outstanding in recent weeks and he might force himself into England contention if that continues.

headline: Aston Villa without four injured players vs Manchester United as Unai Emery gets huge boost
body: Aston Villa news with the latest injury updates emerging ahead of the Premier League clash against Man United

Unai Emery could welcome an injured star back to action for the clash against Manchester United at Villa Park this weekend. The Red Devils head into the clash off the back of two consecutive victories over Wolves and West Ham, while the hosts enter the fixture having surprisingly lost their last two games on home soil.

Injury news is dominating news ahead of the game and while it may appear the likes of United, Tottenham and Liverpool, have been hit harder by injuries, Villa have seen a number of important players miss action. Tyrone Mings and Emi Buendia are both still expected to remain out with long-term injuries picked up back in August.

Nicolo Zaniolo, Diego Carlos, Alex Moreno and Jacob Ramsey have all been affected by injuries this season but the quartet are now all back available. And yet there is still a number of players missing out with Ezri Konsa the latest player to pick up an issue.

In the 5-0 victory against Sheffield United, the versatile defender was forced off just beyond the hour mark with Emery revealing he could be out until March. "He will not be available for three or four weeks, more or less," the Villa boss said on Tuesday.
